california-housing.story: You are a data scientist at a real estate firm in California. Your task is to build a model that can accurately predict median house values in various districts. This will help agents price homes correctly and provide clients with reliable market insights. You'll use a Random Forest model to uncover how different factors influence house prices.

MedInc.description: Median income for households in the block group (in tens of thousands of US Dollars).

HouseAge.description: Median age of a house within a block group.

AveRooms.description: Average number of rooms per household.

AveBedrms.description: Average number of bedrooms per household.

Population.description: Total population of the block group.

Latitude.description: The latitude of the block group.

Longitude.description: The longitude of the block group.

MedHouseVal.description: The median house value for California districts, expressed in hundreds of thousands of dollars ($100,000).

diabetes.story: As a researcher in a medical lab, you are tasked with investigating the progression of diabetes. Using a dataset of patient clinical measurements, your goal is to build a model that can predict the quantitative measure of disease progression one year after baseline. This model will help identify which factors are most critical in predicting the severity of the disease.

DiseaseProgression.description: A quantitative measure of disease progression one year after baseline.

linnerud.story: You're a sports scientist analyzing data from a group of athletes at a fitness center. The dataset contains their performance on three exercises (Chinups, Situps, Jumps) and three physiological measurements (Weight, Waist, Pulse). Your objective is to build a model that predicts an athlete's weight based on their exercise performance, helping to create personalized training programs.

wine-quality.story: You are a quality analyst for a vineyard, and you've been given a dataset of chemical properties for a batch of red wines. Your goal is to build a classification model to determine whether a wine is of 'Good' or 'Bad' quality. This will help streamline the quality control process and ensure only the best wines reach the market.

fixed_acidity.description: The amount of non-volatile acids in the wine.

volatile_acidity.description: The amount of acetic acid in wine, which at high levels can lead to an unpleasant, vinegary taste.

citric_acid.description: Found in small quantities, citric acid can add 'freshness' and flavor to wines.

residual_sugar.description: The amount of sugar remaining after fermentation stops.

chlorides.description: The amount of salt in the wine.

free_sulfur_dioxide.description: The free form of SO2 exists in equilibrium between molecular SO2 (as a dissolved gas) and bisulfite ion.

total_sulfur_dioxide.description: Amount of free and bound forms of S02.

pH.description: Describes how acidic or basic a wine is on a scale from 0 (very acidic) to 14 (very basic).

sulphates.description: A wine additive which can contribute to sulfur dioxide gas (SO2) levels.

alcohol.description: The percentage of alcohol content of the wine.

quality.description: A binary quality score (0 for 'Bad', 1 for 'Good').

breast-cancer.story: Working in a medical research lab, you are tasked with developing a reliable diagnostic tool for breast cancer. Using a dataset of tumor measurements, your mission is to build a classification model that can accurately distinguish between malignant (cancerous) and benign (non-cancerous) tumors. This could be a vital tool in early cancer detection.

mean radius.description: Mean of distances from center to points on the perimeter of the tumor.

mean texture.description: Standard deviation of gray-scale values in the tumor image.

mean smoothness.description: Mean of local variation in radius lengths.

Diagnosis.description: The diagnosis of the tumor (0 for Malignant, 1 for Benign).

digits.story: You're an engineer working on an optical character recognition (OCR) system. Your current task is to build a model that can recognize handwritten digits from 8x8 pixel images. You will train a Random Forest classifier to identify the correct digit (0-9) based on the pixel intensity values provided in the dataset.

pixel_2_2.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 2, column 2.

pixel_2_3.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 2, column 3.

pixel_2_4.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 2, column 4.

pixel_2_5.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 2, column 5.

pixel_3_2.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 3, column 2.

pixel_3_3.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 3, column 3.

pixel_3_4.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 3, column 4.

pixel_3_5.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 3, column 5.

pixel_4_2.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 4, column 2.

pixel_4_3.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 4, column 3.

pixel_4_4.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 4, column 4.

pixel_4_5.description: Intensity of the pixel at row 4, column 5.
